Line 103: Line 103:
Data centers typically have [[raised floor]]ing made up of {{convert|60|cm|ft|abbr=on|0}} removable square tiles. The trend is towards {{convert|80|-|100|cm|in|abbr=on}} void to cater for better and uniform air distribution. These provide a [[plenum space|plenum]] for air to circulate below the floor, as part of the air conditioning system, as well as providing space for power cabling.
Data centers typically have [[raised floor]]ing made up of {{convert|60|cm|ft|abbr=on|0}} removable square tiles. The trend is towards {{convert|80|-|100|cm|in|abbr=on}} void to cater for better and uniform air distribution. These provide a [[plenum space|plenum]] for air to circulate below the floor, as part of the air conditioning system, as well as providing space for power cabling.
â
[[File:powerpole.JPG|thumb|Anderson Powerpole connector]]Some new data centres and technology demonstrations are beginning to standardise a 380VDC power distribution network that is expected to improve efficiency of building power systems<ref>{{cite web|title=ISSUES RELATING TO THE ADOPTION OF HIGHER VOLTAGE DIRECT CURRENT POWER IN THE DATA CENTER|url=http://www.thegreengrid.org/~/media/WhitePapers/IssuesRelatingtotheAdoptionofHVdcPowerintheDataCenter_v1.ashx?lang=en|publisher=The Green Grid|accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|last=http://dcbuildingpowerasia.darnell.com/|title=380Vdc Data Center Power Standard Approved During DC Building Power Japan|url=http://www.powerpulse.net/story.php?storyID=21530|publisher=http://www.powerpulse.net/|accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>. Since much of the power loss in electrical systems is caused by voltage and AC/DC conversion, an all DC network supplying [[low voltage]] (LV) power close to equipment loads is expected to achieve significant savings in power usage and cooling loads<ref>{{cite web|title=Researchers Flip the Switch to Test Energy Saving in Data Centers Using DC Power Directly|url=http://www.calit2.net/newsroom/release.php?id=1730|publisher=Anderson Power Products Inc|accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>. 380VDC power supply requires [[DC connector]]s that prevent them being used on AC equipment, with possible standardisation likely to use connectors such as the Anderson PowerpoleÂ® Pak <ref>{{cite web|title=PowerpoleÂ® Pak Connectors|url=http://andersonpower.com/products/powerpak-powerpole-pak.html|publisher=Anderson Power Products Inc|accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>.
+
[[File:powerpole.JPG|thumb|{{deletable image-caption|Tuesday, 21 June 2011}} Anderson Powerpole connector]]Some new data centres and technology demonstrations are beginning to standardise a 380VDC power distribution network that is expected to improve efficiency of building power systems<ref>{{cite web|title=ISSUES RELATING TO THE ADOPTION OF HIGHER VOLTAGE DIRECT CURRENT POWER IN THE DATA CENTER|url=http://www.thegreengrid.org/~/media/WhitePapers/IssuesRelatingtotheAdoptionofHVdcPowerintheDataCenter_v1.ashx?lang=en|publisher=The Green Grid|accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|last=http://dcbuildingpowerasia.darnell.com/|title=380Vdc Data Center Power Standard Approved During DC Building Power Japan|url=http://www.powerpulse.net/story.php?storyID=21530|publisher=http://www.powerpulse.net/|accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>. Since much of the power loss in electrical systems is caused by voltage and AC/DC conversion, an all DC network supplying [[low voltage]] (LV) power close to equipment loads is expected to achieve significant savings in power usage and cooling loads<ref>{{cite web|title=Researchers Flip the Switch to Test Energy Saving in Data Centers Using DC Power Directly|url=http://www.calit2.net/newsroom/release.php?id=1730|publisher=Anderson Power Products Inc|accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>. 380VDC power supply requires [[DC connector]]s that prevent them being used on AC equipment, with possible standardisation likely to use connectors such as the Anderson PowerpoleÂ® Pak <ref>{{cite web|title=PowerpoleÂ® Pak Connectors|url=http://andersonpower.com/products/powerpak-powerpole-pak.html|publisher=Anderson Power Products Inc|accessdate=16 June 2011}}</ref>.
